{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3721915,"name":"Carter Ryba","username":"10219Ryba","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/10219ryba/{size}/248339_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-23T21:28:16.478Z","cooked":"

So I’m putting together our team’s pre-season parts list, and I get to the battery section. While doing some research, I came across the Zebra Power battery doc (https://drive.google.com/file/d/1QlGaSKlrtTflktHJzugkRzqrJkCVzYjG/view
), and also saw people talking about being able to get 4 AWG wire into SB50 contacts. Long story short, I was wondering which wire you all use for this, and if anything special needs to be done to make it work.

SB120 contacts are literally like 6 times the price so it would be cool if someone could help us save money with this.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":37,"updated_at":"2025-08-24T00:35:29.537Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":21,"reads":413,"readers_count":412,"score":232.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":505610,"topic_slug":"4-awg-in-sb50-contacts","display_username":"Carter Ryba","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://drive.google.com/file/d/1QlGaSKlrtTflktHJzugkRzqrJkCVzYjG/view","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":25}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65624,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"9764, 10219"},"post_url":"/t/4-awg-in-sb50-contacts/505610/1","custom_user_title":"9764, 10219","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3721917,"name":"Ada T","username":"cmdada","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cmdada/{size}/230870_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-23T21:29:55.595Z","cooked":"
10219Ryba:

get 4 AWG wire into SB50 contacts.

Using 4 AWG wire with a SB50 Battery Connector Technical Discussion
We are in the process of trying to decide if we want to use 4 or 6 AWG wire for our wiring from battery to the power distribution board. I have heard of multiple teams doing this but I hadn’t seen a full discussion of if this was a good idea and what to watch out for. The primary reason for not doing this seems to be crimping the wire to the SB50 contacts. Are there other reasons or concerns? I have seen this done correctly but it seems like it can quite easily go astray like in this picture…
","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":37,"updated_at":"2025-08-23T21:29:55.595Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":408,"readers_count":407,"score":116.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":505610,"topic_slug":"4-awg-in-sb50-contacts","display_username":"Ada T","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/using-4-awg-wire-with-a-sb50-battery-connector/419877","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Using 4 AWG wire with a SB50 Battery Connector","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60586,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1157 team captain, 2036 electrical lead 2024"},"post_url":"/t/4-awg-in-sb50-contacts/505610/2","custom_user_title":"1157 team captain, 2036 electrical lead 2024","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3721948,"name":"","username":"Thor5090","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/thor5090/{size}/226064_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-23T23:04:00.670Z","cooked":"

You have to swage the sb50 contacts larger to fit the 4awg wire. We noticed a big difference in the battery cable temperature when changing batteries. Not all our batteries have 4awg wire on them yet, as we get new batteries we are changing them over.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":37,"updated_at":"2025-08-23T23:04:00.670Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":349,"readers_count":348,"score":139.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":505610,"topic_slug":"4-awg-in-sb50-contacts","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53198,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"My views are mine and mine alone"},"post_url":"/t/4-awg-in-sb50-contacts/505610/3","custom_user_title":"My views are mine and mine alone","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3721950,"name":"","username":"FinIce","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/finice/{size}/270519_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-23T23:05:56.651Z","cooked":"

My teams guide on this is here

docs.google.com

Hackbots Electrical Standard Practices Guide (Electrical Manual) 2024-25

This Doc is private

Here are the components.
https://powerwerx.com/welding-cable-epdm (4 Gauge wire)
https://powerwerx.com/anderson-pp75-sb50-loose-piece-contact (SB50 Connector)
https://powerwerx.com/anderson-sb50-loose-piece-housing (SB50 Housing)

With this combination we have found that (although tricky) you can just slide the connector onto the wire with a bit of finesse. Swaging the connector would help get the wires in, but isn’t technically necessary. Be aware that too few strands, and too many strands, on your chosen 4awg wire may mean you can’t use this directly without swaging

PLEASE make sure you get the right sized does, I’m sure @bbonner can talk about that more

Wagg","username":"cad321","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/c57346/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-08-24T00:34:13.189Z","cooked":"

We’ve successfully used the “flexible” 4awg wire from AndyMark and standard SB50 contacts the last 2 years now for our battery cables.

It’s VERY tight, but does fit. The trick we’ve found that’s key to making it work (counterintuitively I might add) is to NOT twist the end of the wire strands before putting it in the contact. Make sure they’re as straight as possible and slowly insert the wire, ensuring no strands fray/stick out. Then just crimp as normal.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":37,"updated_at":"2025-08-24T00:34:13.189Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":295,"readers_count":294,"score":199.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":505610,"topic_slug":"4-awg-in-sb50-contacts","display_username":"Brian Wagg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://andymark.com/products/4-gauge-flexible-wire-10-ft?_pos=7&_psq=4+gauge&_ss=e&_v=1.0","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"4 Gauge Flexible Wire - 10 ft — AndyMark","clicks":14}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":8}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19532,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Brian Wagg"},"post_url":"/t/4-awg-in-sb50-contacts/505610/5","custom_user_title":"Brian Wagg","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":8,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3722068,"name":"Joseph Walters","username":"Jwal","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jwal/{size}/228161_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-24T01:09:42.512Z","cooked":"

The “not twisting” is something people don’t think of when making tight fits with stranded wire.

If you think about what’s happening, the strands of the stranded wire are in their tightest packed form inside the jacket and just stripped without any mechanical bending.

When people twist the wire, you are bending strands and laying them over the top of their neighboring strands - increasing the Outer Diameter of the cable.

You can confirm this visually, and will also note that thoroughly twisted strands will also result in a shorter stripped length than what you strip initially! This is because strand length is consumed by axial distance.

Overall yes! Don’t twist your strands if making a tight fit into a terminal or connector, keep em straight and freshly stripped!

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":37,"updated_at":"2025-08-24T01:09:42.512Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":265,"readers_count":264,"score":253.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":505610,"topic_slug":"4-awg-in-sb50-contacts","display_username":"Joseph Walters","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":19532,"username":"cad321","name":"Brian Wagg","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/c57346/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":12}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63541,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/4-awg-in-sb50-contacts/505610/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":9},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":12,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3722092,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-24T01:27:26.397Z","cooked":"

We put #4 into the SB50 contacts reliably. Yes, its super full!
The key is to strip and stuff; no twisting, no messing with it.
You start with the wire at a bit of an angle to get it started, thrn rotate the balance in. If you get a few strands hanging out, clip later.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":37,"updated_at":"2025-08-24T01:27:26.397Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":247,"readers_count":246,"score":184.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":505610,"topic_slug":"4-awg-in-sb50-contacts","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/4-awg-in-sb50-contacts/505610/7","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3729357,"name":"Dave Morrison","username":"davemorrison","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/8dc957/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-09-02T19:07:13.472Z","cooked":"

We used Battery Cable 4 AWG ( Size 4 Gauge ) Red - Copper Flexible Stranded - By the Foot / Battery Cable 4 AWG ( Size 4 Gauge ) Black - Copper Flexible Stranded - By the Foot which I like for the exceptional (for a 4ga) flexibility and TPE over EPDM jacket. Pricier though. It does not go into an unaltered SB50 contact. Swaging works though, and it doesn’t need much.

Throw the small one of these in a hand drill and swage the connector to fit the 4 AWG wire. It worked for us before we finally made the switch to the SB120.
Yu&Yang 12pcs HVAC Tools Swaging Tool HVAC Copper Pipe Expander Tool with 1/4''， 3/8''，1/2''， 5/8''，3/4''，7/8''Bits Set - Amazon.com

We used these from Grainger for the last 2 seasons:

grainger.com

Whoops, we couldn't find that.

grainger.com

Whoops, we couldn't find that.

They did not require swaging to fit in the SB50 contacts. It’s a tight fit, but it did fit. I don’t think it’s really 4AWG but it does seem bigger than 6AWG. Maybe 5AWG? Some metric size?

We had originally bought 6AWG welding wire from the same manufacturer, and it was a little undersized, so I figured if their 4AWG was also a little on the small side it would fit in the SB50 without modification, which would be perfect.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":37,"updated_at":"2025-09-02T19:38:21.919Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":183,"readers_count":182,"score":51.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":505610,"topic_slug":"4-awg-in-sb50-contacts","display_username":"Ryan Reed","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.grainger.com/product/WESTWARD-Welding-Cable-4-AWG-Conductor-19YD97","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Whoops, we couldn't find that.","clicks":3},{"url":"https://www.grainger.com/product/WESTWARD-Welding-Cable-4-AWG-Conductor-19YE25","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Whoops, we couldn't find that.","clicks":1}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66264,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/4-awg-in-sb50-contacts/505610/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3729439,"name":"JamesCH95","username":"JamesCH95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jamesch95/{size}/1200_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-02T20:10:31.398Z","cooked":"

SB120 housings will last a long, long time. We have purchased them twice, once in 2017 and last year bought a few for new chargers. It’s an investment, but worth it (no screwing around with improperly sized wires, go to 2awg on the battery side!, lower contact resistance, higher pullout and disconnect force, easier to grip for connecting/disconnecting). Every $1 in SB120 will see $100+ in batteries connected through it over the years. Spend the money if you can.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":37,"updated_at":"2025-09-02T20:10:31.398Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":177,"readers_count":176,"score":80.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":505610,"topic_slug":"4-awg-in-sb50-contacts","display_username":"JamesCH95","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":3782,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/4-awg-in-sb50-contacts/505610/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3729443,"name":"AllenGregoryIV","username":"AllenGregoryIV","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/allengregoryiv/{size}/65531_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-02T20:13:31.148Z","cooked":"

Here is a video of how Spectrum did 4 AWG inside the SB50 contacts.

We’ve since moved on to SB120, but that’s a pretty marginal gain over 4AWG in SB50s and much more expensive.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":37,"updated_at":"2025-09-02T20:13:31.148Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":177,"readers_count":176,"score":65.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":505610,"topic_slug":"4-awg-in-sb50-contacts","display_username":"AllenGregoryIV","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MH9MQdLXEIE","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":2}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":10647,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Engineering Coach - Spectrum 3847/Photon 8515"},"post_url":"/t/4-awg-in-sb50-contacts/505610/12","custom_user_title":"Engineering Coach - Spectrum 3847/Photon 8515","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3729483,"name":"Elliot S","username":"ElliotS","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/elliots/{size}/177628_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-02T21:12:53.941Z","cooked":"

If people are sticking with the SB50 connectors is it recommended to have 4 AWG at least on the battery side? Since we use the PDH I am guessing we should stick with 6 AWG on the non battery side to allow that to fit better in the PDH? I saw that mentioned somewhere in the other thread I think, but not sure if that is true. Also, changing from 6 AWG to 4 AWG robot side adds a little weight, and with the new reduced weight we are chasing every ounce.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":37,"updated_at":"2025-09-02T21:12:53.941Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":168,"readers_count":167,"score":58.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":505610,"topic_slug":"4-awg-in-sb50-contacts","display_username":"Elliot S","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50070,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Probably CADing | 2877 LigerBots Alum-Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/4-awg-in-sb50-contacts/505610/13","custom_user_title":"Probably CADing | 2877 LigerBots Alum-Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3729546,"name":"JamesCH95","username":"JamesCH95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jamesch95/{size}/1200_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-02T22:36:33.310Z","cooked":"

Every once of copper helping get electrons to your motors is an ounce well spent. Every system on the robot performs better with upgraded main wiring.

PDH accepts 4awg no problem.

4 AWG on the battery side impacts -every- electrical system on the robot, since all the current goes through it. The price/weight for performance tradeoff is pretty good there! I’m not really on team #2 AWG, though

JamesCH95:

Perhaps you’re using different wire than we were. We tried 4AWG last year for the first time and had a heck of a time trying to get it into the PDH. We used very thin/flexible/high strand count “welding wire”, so the strands just flexed everywhere. Switching to ferrules sounds like a great idea until you realize the Wago connectors are rated for max 6AWG with ferrules (4AWG without)

Its super super super important to get the strip length long enough… Might have suffered from hot connections there before

","post_number":18,"post_type":1,"posts_count":37,"updated_at":"2025-09-03T00:18:31.339Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":17,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":140,"readers_count":139,"score":53.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":505610,"topic_slug":"4-awg-in-sb50-contacts","display_username":"Carter Ryba","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":46443,"username":"Weldingrod1","name":"Rod","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65624,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"9764, 10219"},"post_url":"/t/4-awg-in-sb50-contacts/505610/18","custom_user_title":"9764, 10219","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3730307,"name":"Fletch","username":"Fletch1373","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-03T19:11:28.539Z","cooked":"

We found a source for 5AWG ferrules (cough AliExpress cough) that would work after trimming off a few strand bundles… that said, it’s FAR from ideal.

Weldingrod1:

You MUST get the kids to NOT twist it.

With the really high strand count stuff we were using, twisting wasn’t even the problem (I metaphorically beat that into them very early on), but just stripping the sheath off would end up breaking/fraying the strands. It’s just crazy fragile stuff I guess

","post_number":19,"post_type":1,"posts_count":37,"updated_at":"2025-09-03T19:11:28.539Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":18,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":134,"readers_count":133,"score":56.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":505610,"topic_slug":"4-awg-in-sb50-contacts","display_username":"Fletch","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":65624,"username":"10219Ryba","name":"Carter Ryba","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/10219ryba/{size}/248339_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9105,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades"},"post_url":"/t/4-awg-in-sb50-contacts/505610/19","custom_user_title":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3730845,"name":"JamesCH95","username":"JamesCH95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jamesch95/{size}/1200_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-04T12:45:02.904Z","cooked":"

Welding wire, and other high flexibility wires, are often made with notably twisted conductors because more strand twist means more flexibility (a topic for another day). So you wind up with a big struggle because the overall conductor diameter may be bigger than normal. Here’s a pic of 4awg welding wire I found on the internet.

4bf64c40-b730-5228-ab62-4d64f04bde8e_b8987317-d3a6-40f0-97d8-7ba6cef6fe5c1445×1084 122 KB

We get battery wire, McMaster 6948K92. It actually has more strands vs comparable welding wire, McMaster 7840A92. The extra stands can be fitted because they are twisted less, more like this picture of 4awg battery wire I found.

4-Gauge-25ft-Red-and-Black-OFC-Ground-Cable-Oxygen-Free-Copper-Power-Wire-4-AWG-25--Red---25--Black-The-Wires-Zone-1664587373_774x774774×774 84.4 KB

YMMV by supplier and description.
